The main thing to remember is that tests are there to ensure that desired b=
ehaviour is implemented correctly. That's it (oh, and according to J.B., to=
 ensure that your fear turns to boredom :-)

To this end, you are not testi=
ng methods. Sure, many methods implement a distinct behaviour, but many do =
not. So, in your code, aim for public methods that are the entry point for =
a behaviour and then create private methods as required to help that public=
 method get the behaviour implemented in a clear fashion.

Then .... test t=
he public methods, checking for the side-effects and return value. If there=
 is no side-effect of or return code from a method, then consider sending i=
t to the bit-bucket.

Simon
